key_points: Donald Rumsfeld died peacefully, in contrast to the many lives lost due to wars he launched.
Rumsfeld was a key neoconservative architect of the Bush administration's war efforts post-9/11.
His strategies led to high civilian casualties, particularly in Afghanistan, from military actions.
Under Rumsfeld, the U.S. used cluster bombs in Afghanistan that inadvertently endangered civilians.
Rumsfeld's Pentagon was criticized for keeping journalists away from frontlines and controlling information.
He played a pivotal role in prioritizing the invasion of Iraq, using 9/11 as justification for targeting the country.
Rumsfeld had a long-standing interest in Iraq, supporting initiatives for regime change years before the Iraq War.
He previously interacted with Saddam Hussein in the 1980s to support Iraq against Iran, providing arms and intelligence.
Rumsfeld was embroiled in controversy when his past support for Saddam Hussein was highlighted during the Iraq War preparations.
Despite controversies and criticisms, Rumsfeld remained a defining figure in U.S. military and foreign policy.
